Formulae.Title: The Centripetal Force for Circular Motion
Formulae.Interpretation: For an object to move along a circular path, there must be a force pointing towards the centre of the circle with a magnitude that is proportional to the mass of the object and its linear velocity squared, and inversely proportional to the radius of the circle.

Identifiers.Definition: is the magnitude of the centripetal force experienced by the object
is the mass of the object
is the tangential speed / linear velocity of the object
is the radius of the circular path

Variants.Title: Vector Form
Variants.Interpretation: Since the direction of the force is always towards the centre of the circle, and the magnitude is constant, the vector notation is often dropped, and only the magnitude of the force is given. This variant is the full vector form of the formula.

Variants.Title: Vector Form in terms of Angular Velocity

Formulae.Title: The Compton Scattering Formula
Formulae.Interpretation: The change in the wavelength of a high-energy photon that scatters off an electron depends on the mass of the electron and the scattering angle.

Identifiers.Definition: is the wavelength of the scattered photon
is the wavelength of the incident photon
is the Reduced Planck Constant
is the mass of the electron
is the speed of light in free space
is the scattering angle of the photon.

Formulae.Title: Coulomb's Law
Formulae.Interpretation: The magnitude of the force between two point charges is directly proportional to the product of the two charges and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

Identifiers.Definition: is the magnitude of the force experienced by each point charge
is the Coulomb Constant, equal to $\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}$
is the electric charge of the first point charge
is the electric charge of the second point charge
is the distance between the point charges

Variants.Title: In terms of the permittivity of free space
Vector form in terms of the permittivity of free space

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Acceleration
Formulae.Interpretation: The acceleration of an object is the rate of change in that object's velocity. It can be expressed mathematically as the derivative of the velocity with respect to time.

Identifiers.Definition: is the acceleration of the object
is the velocity of the object
is time

Variants.Title: Motion in One Dimension
Variants.Interpretation: If only motion in one dimension is being examined, the vector notation can be dropped.

Variants.Title: Constant or Average Acceleration
Variants.Interpretation: If the acceleration is constant over the period of time being examined, the acceleration can be expressed as just the difference between the final and initial acceleration divided by the time period.

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Angular Acceleration
Formulae.Interpretation: Angular acceleration is the rate of change of angular velocity.

Identifiers.Definition: is the angular acceleration
is the angular velocity
is time

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Angular Frequency
Formulae.Interpretation: Angular frequency is the number of counts per unit time that a rotating system completes one full rotation, or an oscillating system completes one full oscillation, where one full rotation or oscillation is represented as $2 \pi$ radians.

Identifiers.Definition: is the angular frequency
is the period of rotation or oscillation

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Angular Impulse
Formulae.Interpretation: The angular impulse is the integral of the torque over time.

Identifiers.Definition: is the angular impulse
is the torque
is time

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Angular Momentum
Formulae.Interpretation: The angular momentum of an object moving along a circular path is the vector product of its radial position and its linear momentum.

Identifiers.Definition: is the angular momentum of the object
is the radial position of the object
is the linear momentum of the object

Variants.Title: In terms of moment of inertia
Variants.Interpretation: The angular momentum of an object or a group of objects can also be expressed as the product of its moment of inertia and its angular velocity.

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Angular Velocity
Formulae.Interpretation: Angular velocity is the rate of change of angular position.

Identifiers.Definition: is the angular velocity
is the angular position
is time

Variants.Title: In terms of Cartesian position and velocity vectors
In terms of Cartesian position and velocity for circular motion
Variants.Interpretation: If an object is moving along a circular path, the radial distance is constant, and the velocity is always perpendicular to the radial position vector, thus the vector product can be dropped, and the magnitude of the radial distance and the tangential velocity can be used.

Formulae.Title: The Definition of the de Broglie Wavelength
Formulae.Interpretation: The de Broglie wavelength is the wavelength associated with a massive particle, and is dependent on the particle's momentum.

Identifiers.Definition: is the de Broglie wavelength of the particle
is the Planck Constant
is the momentum of the particle

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Density
Formulae.Interpretation: For an object made of a homogenous material, the density of that object is its mass divided by its volume.

Identifiers.Definition: is the density of the object
is the mass of the object
is the volume of the object

Variants.Title: The Density of an Inhomogenous Material
Variants.Interpretation: For an object where the density is not constant throughout, the density of an infinitesimal volume, $\mathrm{d}V$, is the derivative of the mass with respect to the volume.

Variants.Title: Mass in terms of Density for an Inhomogenous Material
Variants.Interpretation: The mass of an object is equal to the integral of its density over its volume.

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Efficiency
Formulae.Interpretation: The efficiency of a process is the ratio of its useful energy or power output to its total energy or power input.

Identifiers.Definition: is the efficiency of the process
is the useful energy output of the process
is the total energy input of the process

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Electric Flux
Formulae.Interpretation: The electric flux through a surface is equal to the integral of the scalar product of the electric field and the normal to the surface. In a uniform electric field, if a flat surface is perpendicular to the direction of the electric field, then the electric flux is equal to the field strength multiplied by the area of the surface. If the surface is parallel to the field, then the flux is zero.

Identifiers.Definition: is the electric flux
is the surface being integrated over
is the electric field
is an infinitesimal area on the surface $S$

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Frequency
Formulae.Interpretation: The frequency of an oscillating or rotating system is the inverse of the period of oscillation or rotation.

Identifiers.Definition: is the frequency of the oscillation or rotation
is the period of the oscillation or rotation

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Heat Capacity
Formulae.Interpretation: The heat capacity of an object is the amount of heat needed to raise the temperature of the object by 1 degree.

Identifiers.Definition: is the heat capacity of the object
is the heat being transferred to the object
is the temperature of the object

Variants.Title: The Specific Heat Capacity
Variants.Interpretation: The specific heat capacity of a material is its heat capacity per unit mass.

Variants.Title: The Heat Capacity at Constant Volume
Variants.Interpretation: The heat capacity at a constant volume is how much heat is needed to raise the temperature of an object by increasing the pressure but keeping the volume constant.

Variants.Title: The Heat Capacity at Constant Pressure
Variants.Interpretation: The heat capacity at a constant pressure is how much heat is needed to raise the temperature of an object allowing the volume to increase but keeping the pressure constant.

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Impulse
Formulae.Interpretation: The impulse experienced by an object is the integral over time of the force applied to it. Since force is a derivative of momentum with respect to time, an impulse is a change in the momentum of an object.

Identifiers.Definition: is the impulse experienced by the object
is the force applied to the object
is time

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Kinetic Energy
Formulae.Interpretation: The kinetic energy of an object moving at non-relativistic speeds is proportional to the mass of the object and its speed squared.

Identifiers.Definition: is the kinetic energy of the object
is the mass of the object
is the speed / the magnitude of the velocity of the object

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Momentum
Formulae.Interpretation: The momentum of an object is the product of its mass and its velocity.

Identifiers.Definition: is the momentum of the object
is the mass of the object
is the velocity of the object

Variants.Title: The Magnitude of the Momentum
Variants.Interpretation: If only the magnitude of the momentum is of interest, the vector notation can be dropped.

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Photon Energy
Formulae.Interpretation: The energy of a photon is equal to the frequency of the photon multiplied by the Planck Constant.

Identifiers.Definition: is the energy of the photon
is the Planck Constant
is the frequency of the photon

Variants.Title: In terms of the wavelength of the photon

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Power
Formulae.Interpretation: Power is the rate of transfer or consumption of energy.

Identifiers.Definition: is the power
is the energy transferred or consumed
is time

Variants.Title: Constant or Average Power
Variants.Interpretation: If the power is constant over the period of time being examined, the power can be expressed as just the amount of energy transferred or consumed divided by the time period.

Variants.Title: Energy used as a function of power and time
Variants.Interpretation: The energy used by a process can be found by multiplying the power by the time period (if the power is constant).

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Pressure
Formulae.Interpretation: The pressure on a surface is the force exerted on that surface per unit area, where the force is constant over the area.

Identifiers.Definition: is the pressure on the surface
is the magnitude of the normal force applied to the surface
is the area of the surface

Variants.Title: Force as an Integral of Pressure
Variants.Interpretation: The total force being applied to a surface is the integral of the pressure on that surface over the area.

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Relativistic Kinetic Energy
Formulae.Interpretation: The relativistic kinetic energy of an object is equal to the Lorentz Factor minus one, multiplied by the rest mass of the object, multiplied by the speed of light squared.

Identifiers.Definition: is the relativistic kinetic energy of the object
is the Lorentz Factor
is the rest mass of the object
is the speed of light in free space

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Relativistic Momentum
Formulae.Interpretation: The relativistic momentum of an object is its mass multiplied by its observed velocity, multiplied by the Lorentz Factor, where the Lorentz Factor is based on the relative speed of the rest frame of the observer and the rest frame of the object.

Identifiers.Definition: is the relativistic vector momentum of the object
is the Lorentz Factor
is the rest mass of the object
is the vector velocity of the object

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Rotational Kinetic Energy
Formulae.Interpretation: The rotational kinetic energy is simply the kinetic energy of a rotating body. It has a similar form to the formula for linear kinetic energy, but the mass is replaced with the moment of inertia, and the velocity is replaced with the angular velocity.

Identifiers.Definition: is the rotational kinetic energy
is the moment of inertia
is the angular velocity

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Rotational Power
Formulae.Interpretation: Rotational power is the torque multiplied by the angular velocity.

Identifiers.Definition: is the power
is the torque
is the angular velocity

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Rotational Work
Formulae.Interpretation: Rotational work is the integral of torque over the angle traversed.

Identifiers.Definition: is the work done
is the torque
is the angular position

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Torque
Formulae.Interpretation: Torque, or moment, or moment of force, is rotational force. For point particles, the torque is the vector cross product of the position vector and the force vector.

Identifiers.Definition: is the torque
is the position
is the force

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Velocity
Formulae.Interpretation: The velocity of an object is the rate of change in that object's position. It can be expressed mathematically as the derivative of position with respect to time.

Identifiers.Definition: is the velocity of the object
is the position of the object
is time

Variants.Title: Motion in One Dimension
Variants.Interpretation: If only motion in one dimension is being examined, the vector notation can be dropped.

Variants.Title: Constant or Average Velocity
Variants.Interpretation: If the velocity is constant over the period of time being examined, the velocity can be expressed as just the difference between the final and initial position divided by the time period.

Formulae.Title: The Definition of Work Done by a Force
Formulae.Interpretation: The work done by a force on an object is the integral of that force over the distance travelled.

Identifiers.Definition: is the work done by the force
is the force applied to the object

Variants.Title: Where the force is parallel to the direction of motion
Variants.Interpretation: If the force is always parallel to the direction of motion, the vector dot product notation can be dropped.

Variants.Title: Where the force is constant
Variants.Interpretation: If the force is constant, and always parallel to the direction of motion, the integral just becomes an integral over the length.

Variants.Title: Where the force is at a constant angle
Variants.Interpretation: If the force is constant, and always at an angle $\theta$ to the direction of motion, the integral just becomes the magnitude of the force multiplied by cosine of $\theta$.

Formulae.Title: The Elastic Potential Energy of an Ideal Spring
Formulae.Interpretation: The potential energy stored in a spring is proportional to the square of the displacement of the spring from its equilibrium position.

Identifiers.Definition: is the elastic potential energy stored in the spring
is the spring constant of the spring
is the displacement of the spring from its equilibrium position

Formulae.Title: The Electric Field of a Point Charge
Formulae.Interpretation: The magnitude of the electric field produced by a point charge is directly proportional to the value of the charge and inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the charge.

Identifiers.Definition: is the magnitude of the electric field
is the Coulomb Constant, equal to $\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}$
is the electric charge of the point charge
is the distance from the charge

Variants.Title: In terms of the permittivity of free space
Vector form in terms of the permittivity of free space

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Electric Potential Energy of Two Point Charges
Formulae.Interpretation: The electric potential energy of two point charges is directly proportional to the product of the two charges, and inversely proportional to the distance between them.

Identifiers.Definition: is the electric potential energy
is the Coulomb Constant, equal to $\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}$
is the electric charge of the first point charge
is the electric charge of the second point charge
is the distance between the charges

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Absolute Electric Potential of a Point Charge
Formulae.Interpretation: The absolute electric potential at a distance $r$ from a point charge is directly proportional to the size of the charge, $q$, and inversely proportional to the distance $r$.

Identifiers.Definition: is the absolute electric potential
is the Coulomb Constant, equal to $\frac{1}{4 \pi \epsilon_{0}}$
is the electric charge of the point charge
is the distance from the charge

Formulae.Title: The Galilean Transformation for Position
Formulae.Interpretation: The position of an object in frame $S^{\prime}$, which moves with a velocity $\textbf{v}$ relative to frame $S$, is offset to its position in $S$ by $-\textbf{v}t$.

Identifiers.Definition: is the position of the object in frame $S$
is the position of the object in frame $S^{\prime}$
is the velocity of frame $S^{\prime}$ relative to $S$
is the time since the origin of the two frames was at the same point

Formulae.Title: The Galilean Transformation for Time
Formulae.Interpretation: Time is the same in all inertial reference frames.

Identifiers.Definition: is the time of an event in frame $S$
is the time of an event in frame $S^{\prime}$

Formulae.Title: Gauss Law for Electricity
Formulae.Interpretation: The divergence of the electric field is directly proportional to the charge density.

Identifiers.Definition: is the electric field
is the charge density
is the permittivity of free space

Variants.Title: Integral Form
Variants.Interpretation: The electric flux through a closed surface is proportional to the charge contained by that surface.

Formulae.Title: Gauss' Law for Gravity
Formulae.Interpretation: The divergence of the gravitational field is directly proportional to the mass density.

Identifiers.Definition: is the gravitational field
is the universal gravitational constant
is the mass density

Variants.Title: Integral Form
Variants.Interpretation: The left hand side of the equation is the gravitational flux. The gravitational flux through a closed surface is proportional to the mass enclosed by the surface.

Formulae.Title: Gauss Law for Magnetism
Formulae.Interpretation: The divergence of the magnetic field is zero. There are no magnetic monopoles.

Identifiers.Definition: is the magnetic field

Variants.Title: Integral Form
Variants.Interpretation: The magnetic flux through any closed surface is zero.

Formulae.Title: The Gravitational Potential Energy for a Uniform Field
Formulae.Interpretation: For a uniform gravitational field, the potential energy of an object increases linearly with height.

Identifiers.Definition: is the gravitational potential energy of an object at a given relative height
is the mass of the object
is the acceleration due to gravity
is the height above a given reference point

Formulae.Title: The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle for Position and Momentum
Formulae.Interpretation: The uncertainty in the position of a wave-particle is inversely proportional to the uncertainty in the momentum of the wave-particle.

Identifiers.Definition: is the uncertainty in the position of the wave-particle
is the uncertainty in the momentum of the wave-particle
is the Reduced Planck Constant

Formulae.Title: The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle for Time and Energy
Formulae.Interpretation: The uncertainty in the lifetime of a wave-particle is inversely proportional to the uncertainty in the energy of the wave-particle.

Identifiers.Definition: is the uncertainty in the lifetime of the wave-particle
is the uncertainty in the energy of the wave-particle
is the Reduced Planck Constant

Formulae.Title: Hooke's Law
Formulae.Interpretation: For an ideal spring, the amount of force needed to compress or extend a spring by a given distance, $x$, is proportional to $x$.

Identifiers.Definition: is the force exerted by the spring
is the spring constant - a constant factor dependent on the properties of the spring, such as the stiffness of the material
is the amount by which the spring has been extended or compressed from its equilibrium point

Formulae.Title: Hubble's Law
Formulae.Interpretation: The recessional velocity of a distant galaxy is directly proportional to the radial distance to that galaxy from the observer.

Identifiers.Definition: is the recessional velocity of the galaxy
is the Hubble Constant
is the radial distance to the galaxy

Formulae.Title: The Ideal Gas Law
Formulae.Interpretation: For an ideal gas, the pressure is proportional to the temperature, $P \propto T$, and the volume is also proportional to the temperature, $V \propto T$, but the pressure is inversely proportional to the volume, $P \propto \frac{1}{V}$.

Identifiers.Definition: is the pressure of the gas
is the volume of the gas
is the number of molecules in the gas
is the Boltzmann Constant
is the temperature of the gas

Variants.Title: In terms of the number of Moles
Variants.Interpretation: where $n$ is the number of moles of the gas and $R$ is the ideal gas constant.

Formulae.Title: The Kelvin-Stokes Theorem
Formulae.Interpretation: The integral of the curl of a vector field across a surface is equal to the integral of the vector field around the closed line bounding the surface.

Identifiers.Definition: is any surface
is a vector field
is the normal vector to an infinitesimal area of the surface $S$
is the closed line bounding the surface
is an infinitesimal segment of line $L$

Formulae.Title: Kepler's Third Law of Planetary Motion
Formulae.Interpretation: The square of the orbital period of a planet is directly proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis of its orbit.

Identifiers.Definition: is the length of the semi-major axis of the planet's orbit
is the planet's orbital period
is the Universal Gravitational Constant
is the mass of the Sun
is the mass of the planet

Variants.Title: Where the mass of the planet is much less than the mass of the Sun

Formulae.Title: The Law of the Photoelectric Effect
Formulae.Interpretation: The maximum kinetic energy of an electron ejected from a material that has been exposed to light of frequency $f$ is equal to the energy of each photon, $hf$, minus the work function, $\phi$.

Identifiers.Definition: is the maximum kinetic energy of the ejected electrons
is Planck's constant
is the frequency of the incident light
is the work function of the material

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Length Contraction Formula in Special Relativity
Formulae.Interpretation: For two points in space in the same frame of reference, for an observer moving at a constant speed $u$ relative to the rest frame of the two points, the observed distance between the points $l$ is equal to the observed distance as measured in the rest frame of the two points, $l_0$, divided by the Lorentz Factor $\gamma$. Lengths in a frame of reference with a relative velocity $u$ will appear shorter than in the rest frame.

Identifiers.Definition: is the distance between two points in space as measured by an observer moving at a speed $u$ relative to the rest frame of the two points
is the distance between two points in space as measured by an observer in the rest frame of the two points
is the Lorentz Factor

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: Linear Thermal Expansion
Formulae.Interpretation: For a rod made of a given material, with a coefficient of linear expansion $\alpha$, the change in the length of the rod is proportional to the change in the temperature of the rod.

Identifiers.Definition: is the change in the length of the rod
is the coefficient of linear expansion of the material
is the initial length of the rod
is the change in the temperature of the rod

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Lorentz Factor
Formulae.Interpretation: The Lorentz Factor is a factor commonly used in equations in Special Relativity. As the relative speed of a reference frame, $u$, approaches the speed of light, $c$, the Lorentz Factor $\gamma$ approaches infinity.

Identifiers.Definition: is the Lorentz Factor
is the relative speed of the inertial reference frame
is the speed of light in free space

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Lorentz Velocity Transformation
Formulae.Interpretation: When $v_x$ and $u$ are both much smaller than $c$, the denominator of this equation approaches $1$, and $v_x^{\prime} \rightarrow v_x - u$, which is the Galilean velocity transformation. In the case where $v_x = c$, $v_x^{\prime} = c$, which is Einstein's Second Postulate.

Identifiers.Definition: is a velocity as measured in the frame of reference $S$
is a velocity as measured in the frame of reference $S^{\prime}$
is the speed of frame $S^{\prime}$ relative to frame $S$
is the speed of light in free space

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Maxwell-Faraday Equation
Formulae.Interpretation: The curl of the electric field is directly proportional to the rate of change of a time-varying magnetic field.

Identifiers.Definition: is the electric field
is the magnetic field
is time

Variants.Title: Integral Form
Variants.Interpretation: The integral of the electric field around a closed path is proportional to the rate of change of the magnetic flux through that surface.

Formulae.Title: Newton's Law of Gravitation
Formulae.Interpretation: Every point mass is attracted to every single other point mass by a force pointing along a line intersecting both points. The magnitude of the force is proportional to the product of the two masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

Identifiers.Definition: is the magnitude of the force between the two masses
is the universal gravitational constant
is the mass of the first object
is the mass of the second object
is the distance between the two objects

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: Newtons Second Law of Motion
Formulae.Interpretation: The force experienced by an object is defined as the rate of change of the momentum of the object. This is expressed mathematically as the derivative of the momentum with respect to time.

Identifiers.Definition: is the force experienced by the object
is the momentum of the object
is time

Variants.Title: Where mass is constant
Variants.Interpretation: If the mass of the object remains constant, then it can be brought outside the derivative, and the force is just equal to the mass multiplied by the acceleration of the object.

Variants.Title: Scalar Form
Variants.Interpretation: If only motion along one dimension is considered, the scalar form can be used.

Variants.Title: Scalar form where mass is constant
Average Force
Variants.Content: F_{\text{average}} = \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} = m \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}

Formulae.Title: Ohm's Law
Formulae.Interpretation: The current through an electrical conductor is directly proportional to the potential difference across it.

Identifiers.Definition: is the current through the conductor
is the potential difference across the conductor
is the resistance of the conductor

Formulae.Title: The Formula for the Total Potential Difference across Electrical Components Connected in Series
Formulae.Interpretation: For electrical components that are connected in series, the total potential difference across all of the components is the sum of the potential difference across each component.

Identifiers.Definition: is the total potential difference across all components
is the potential difference across component $j$

Formulae.Title: The Potential Energy of an Electric Dipole in an Electric Field
Formulae.Interpretation: The potential energy of an electric dipole in an electric field is equal to the scalar product of the electric dipole moment and the electric field.

Identifiers.Definition: is the potential energy
is the electric dipole moment
is the electric field

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Power Transferred by an Electrical Component
Formulae.Interpretation: The power transferred by an electrical component is equal to the product of the current through the component and the electric potential difference across it.

Identifiers.Definition: is the power transferred by the electrical component
is the current through the component
is the potential difference across the component

Variants.Title: In terms of current and resistance

Formulae.Title: The Pressure at a Given Depth in a Liquid
Formulae.Interpretation: The pressure at a given depth, $h$, in a liquid is proportional to $h$, the density of the liquid, and the strength of the local gravitational field.

Identifiers.Definition: is the pressure at a given depth
is the depth below the surface of the liquid
is the density of the liquid
is the local acceleration due to gravity

Formulae.Title: Radial Acceleration in Uniform Circular Motion
Formulae.Interpretation: For an object moving in perfectly circular motion, the instantaneous acceleration of that object at each point along the radius of the circle is proportional to the velocity squared and inversely proportional to the radius of the circle.

Identifiers.Definition: is the instantaneous acceleration of the object at each point along the path, pointing along the radius of the circle
is the magnitude of the velocity of the object
is the radius of the circle

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Radioactive Decay Formula
Formulae.Interpretation: The activity of a radioactive sample decreases exponentially with time.

Identifiers.Definition: is the activity of the sample at a time $t$
is the activity of the sample at time $t = 0$
is the decay constant of the radioisotope
is time

Formulae.Title: The Relativistic Doppler Effect
Formulae.Interpretation: When an electromagnetic wave source is moving towards an observer, the observed frequency is greater than the emitted frequency. When an electromagnetic wave source is moving away from an observer, the observed frequency is less than the emitted frequency. Thus light from objects moving towards an observer appears bluer, and light from objects moving away from an observer appears redder.

Identifiers.Definition: is the emitted frequency of the wave
is the observed frequency of the wave
is the speed at which the wave source is moving towards the observer
is the speed of light in free space

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Formula for the Total Resistance of Electrical Components Connected in Series
Formulae.Interpretation: For electrical components that are connected in series, the total resistance of all of the components is the sum of the resistance of each component.

Identifiers.Definition: is the total resistance of all of the components
is the resistance of component $j$

Formulae.Title: The Kinematic Equation for Distance as a Function of Time for Constant Acceleration
Formulae.Interpretation: For an object under constant acceleration, the distance travelled by that object as a function of time is given by a quadratic formula with respect to time.

Identifiers.Definition: is the position of the object at a time $t$
is the position of the object at time $t = 0$
is the initial velocity of the object
is the acceleration of the object
is time

Formulae.Title: The Kinematic Equation for Distance as a Function of Time for Constant Acceleration (Using u and v)
Formulae.Interpretation: For an object under constant acceleration, the distance travelled by that object as a function of time is given by the average velocity of the object multiplied by time.

Identifiers.Definition: is the position of the object at a time $t$
is the position of the object at time $t = 0$
is the initial velocity of the object
is the final velocity of the object
is time

Formulae.Title: The Kinematic Equation for Final Velocity as a Function of Time for Constant Acceleration
Formulae.Interpretation: For an object under constant acceleration, the final velocity of that object is equal to the initial velocity plus the acceleration times time.

Identifiers.Definition: is the velocity of the object at time $t$
is the initial velocity of the object
is the acceleration of the object, which does not vary with time
is time

Formulae.Title: The Kinematic Equation for Final Velocity as a Function of Distance for Constant Acceleration
Formulae.Interpretation: For an object under constant acceleration, the square of the object's final velocity is equal to the square of the initial velocity plus two times the acceleration times the distance travelled.

Identifiers.Definition: is the final velocity of the object
is the initial velocity of the object
is the acceleration of the object, which does not vary with time
is the distance travelled by the object

Formulae.Title: The Time-Dependent Schrdinger Equation
Formulae.Interpretation: The Time-Dependent Schrdinger Equation is the wave equation for a single, non-relativistic particle moving in a potential $V(\textbf{r}, t)$.
Formulae.Content: i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \Psi (\textbf{r}, t) = \left( \frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 \mu} \nabla^{2} + V (\textbf{r}, t) \right) \Psi (\textbf{r}, t)

Identifiers.Definition: is the imaginary constant
is the Reduced Planck Constant
is time
is the wave function of the particle
is position
is the reduced mass of the particle
is the potential

Formulae.Title: The Time Dilation Formula in Special Relativity
Formulae.Interpretation: For two events that occur at the same point in space, for an observer moving at a constant speed $u$ relative to the rest frame of the two events, the observed time interval between the two events $\Delta t$ will be equal to the observed time interval as measured in the rest frame of the two events, $\Delta t_0$ multiplied by the Lorentz Factor, $\gamma$.

Identifiers.Definition: is the time interval as measured by an observer moving at a speed $u$ relative to the rest frame of the two events
is the time interval as measured by an observer in the rest frame of the two events
is the Lorentz Factor of Special Relativity

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Torque on an Electric Dipole
Formulae.Interpretation: The torque exerted on an electric dipole in the presence of an electric field is the vector product of the electric dipole moment and the electric field.

Identifiers.Definition: is the torque
is the electric dipole moment
is the electric field

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Total Relativistic Energy of an Object
Formulae.Interpretation: The total energy of a moving object is equal to the Lorentz Factor, multiplied by the rest mass of the object, multiplied by the speed of light squared. In the case where the object is at rest, the Lorentz Factor is equal to $1$, and the total energy of the object is just its rest mass multiplied by the speed of light squared.

Identifiers.Definition: is the total relativistic energy of the object
is the Lorentz Factor
is the rest mass of the object
is the speed of light in free space

References.Title: Sears and Zemansky's University Physics with Modern Physics

Formulae.Title: The Wave Speed Formula
Formulae.Interpretation: The speed of a non-dispersive wave is equal to the frequency of the wave multiplied by its wavelength.

Identifiers.Definition: is the speed of the wave
is the frequency of the wave
is the wavelength of the wave

Constants.Title: The Avogadro Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Avogadro Constant is the number of constituent particles that are contained in the amount of substance given by one mole.

Constants.Title: The Bohr Magneton
Constants.Interpretation: The Bohr Magneton is a physical constant for expressing the magnetic moment of an electron caused by its orbital or spin angular momentum.

Constants.Title: The Bohr Radius
Constants.Interpretation: The Bohr Radius is a physical constant that is approximately equal to the most probable distance between the nucleus and the electron in a hydrogen atom in its ground state.

Constants.Title: The Boltzmann Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Boltzmann Constant is a physical constant that relates the average kinetic energy of particles in a gas to the temperature of the gas.

Constants.Title: The Coulomb Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Coulomb Constant is a constant of proportionality in the equations governing electrodynamics.

Constants.Title: Elementary Charge
Constants.Interpretation: The Elementary Charge is the charge carried by a single proton, and the magnitude of the charge carried by a single electron.

Constants.Title: The Electron Rest Mass
Constants.Interpretation: The Electron Rest Mass is the mass of an electron as measured in the rest frame of an electron.

Constants.Title: The Faraday Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Faraday Constant is a physical constant that represents the magnitude of electric charge per mole of electrons.

Constants.Title: The Ideal Gas Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Ideal Gas Constant is a physical constant that is equivalent to the Boltzmann Constant but expressed in units of energy per temperature increment per mole.

Constants.Title: The Neutron Rest Mass
Constants.Interpretation: The Neutron Rest Mass is the mass of a neutron as measured in the rest frame of the neutron.

Constants.Title: The Permeability of Free Space / The Vacuum Permeability
Constants.Interpretation: The permeability of free space is an ideal physical constant which is the value of magnetic permeability in a classical vacuum.

Constants.Title: The Permittivity of Free Space / The Vacuum Permittivity
Constants.Interpretation: The permittivity of free space is an ideal physical constant which is the value of the absolute dielectric permittivity of a classical vacuum.

Constants.Title: The Planck Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Planck Constant is used in the description of a number of physical phenomena, including blackbody radiation, the photoelectric effect, and the uncertainty principle.

Constants.Title: The Proton Rest Mass
Constants.Interpretation: The Proton Rest Mass is the mass of a proton as measured in the rest frame of a proton.

Constants.Title: The Reduced Planck Constant (the Dirac Constant)
Constants.Interpretation: The Reduced Planck Constant is equal to the Planck Constant divided by $2 \pi$, which is a more convenient value to use in many equations.

Constants.Title: The Rydberg Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Rydberg Constant is a physical constant that represents the limiting value of the wavenumber of the lowest-energy photon capable of ionising a hydrogen atom from its ground state.

Constants.Title: The Speed of Light in Free Space
Constants.Interpretation: The speed of light in free space is the hypothetical 'speed limit' of the universe. Nothing is known to travel faster than this speed.

Constants.Title: The Stefan-Boltzmann Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Stefan-Boltzmann Constant is a physical constant that relates the total energy radiated per unit surface area of a black body across all wavelengths to the temperature of the object.

Constants.Title: The Unified Atomic Mass Unit
Constants.Interpretation: The Unified Atomic Mass Unit is a standard unit of mass that quantifies mass on an atomic scale. One unified atomic mass unit is approximately equal to the mass of one nucleon.

Constants.Title: The Universal Gravitational Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The universal gravitational constant is an empirical physical constant used in the calculation of gravitational effects in Newton's Law of Gravitation and Einstein's General Theory of Relativity.

Constants.Title: The Wien Displacement Constant
Constants.Interpretation: The Wien Displacement Constant is a physical constant that relates the inverse of the temperature of a black body to the peak wavelength of the radiation emitted by that object.
